sentence.idiomatic: There is a big pile of toys at his house.
Every time they go to the supermarket she kicks up a fuss to get her mom to buy a toy.
You're so big already, and you still want to play with toys?
Things change so quickly. The mobile phone I bought a year ago is already like an antique.
It's very normal for young people to hold hands--you can't even accept that? Apparently you're a real dinosaur.
You old fogy, it's the twenty-first century. Don't be so conservative, all right?
Pretend you're a policeman, and go scare him.
When he came in, I pretended I was sleeping.
I am plainly right in front of you, yet you pretend not to see me. It's too much!
You don't even know what rock-climbing is. It seems you are really behind the times.
How come I can't at all understand what you are talking about? Am I that behind the times?
In order to keep up-to-date, she reads fashion magazines every day.
He has lived frugally for these past few months just to be able to buy one concert ticket.
It's not easy being a parent. In order to send one's child to the best schools, one must live very frugally.
In order to buy a home, from now on everyone in the family will have to live frugally.
She bought an electric razor for me, it's really handy.
What do you think is better: an electric toothbrush, or a regular toothbrush?
As soon as the kid saw the battery-operated toy car, he wanted it.
My remote control airplane suddenly dropped out of the sky, and smashed.
Once you have this remote control, you'll be able to sit in the office and easily control everything in your home by remote.
Under scientists' remote control, robots are able to take the place of humans in carrying out dangerous work.
We're bros--of course we need to share our fortunes, divide our miseries.
Nowadays all anyone cares about is money. It's difficult to find a friend to share in one's fortunes, divide one's disasters.
I've said it before: share in fortunes, divide disasters. When I met with misfortune you did your best to help me. Now that I am successful, of course I want to share it with you.
Toys these days may be well made, but they're definitely not as fun as the ones from my childhood.
How's that possible? You didn't have any toys back then, right?

Ah, you don't understand. The toys from my childhood were simple, but we never got tired of them. For example, wooden blocks, marbles, bean bags, and ``foot shuttlecocks." As soon as I got out of school, I'd get together with a big group of classmates to play. Ah, what a shame... these are all so outdated now, no one plays with them.
The ones you mentioned were all toys for boys. What did the girls play with back then?

When we were little we didn't have much. Those were the toys we had, so we didn't differentiate between boys' and girls' toys. Some people didn't even have any toys. They could just play games; either the ``big rubber band" or ``drop the handkerchief."
When I was little it was a lot better. Boys had toy guns and toy cars, and we girls had lots of dolls. We'd play house all day, pretending we were the dolls' mothers.

A mother's instinct at such a young age. Looking at the toys nowadays, you could say we've fallen behind the times. When my son was little, we started having imported toys: Transformers, Barbie dolls, and what have you. As parents, in order to buy toys for our children, we'd have to live simply.
Yeah. Have you ever noticed that the games from before involved quite a few people competing, like marbles, or kicking the shuttlecock? But nowadays the toys only need one person.

Yes, with these electric, remote control things, you just flip a switch and they move on their own, and even fly! Maybe it's because now everyone is an only child. It's not like it was for us. We could play with our brothers and sisters.
If only I knew, I would have saved the toys to give to my own children. Let them see how daddy and mommy grew up. Let them learn the meaning of ``sharing fortune, dividing disaster."
